Q: Why does Publius argue for a large republic?
ExpA: It better controls factions through diversity of interests
A:
Short answer — because a larger republic (within a practicable sphere) is likelier to elect capable "guardians" and to govern itself well: it enlarges the pool of qualified candidates, reduces the danger of local cabals, and (unlike a pure democracy) a representative republic can be extended over a wide region.

Key points Publius makes (from the text):
- "whether small or extensive republics are more favorable to the election of proper guardians of the public weal ... clearly decided in favor of the latter" (larger republic better for electing proper guardians). (d1e589b1-8403-45d8-bfd0-930d86103b94)
- "the larger the society, provided it lie within a practical sphere, the more duly capable it will be of self-government. And happily for the REPUBLICAN CAUSE, the practicable sphere may be carried to a very great extent, by a judicious modification and mixture of the FEDERAL PRINCIPLE." (fff4fe40-92ed-4b55-b221-003725607412)
- A republic (representation) can be extended over a large region, while a democracy (people governing in person) is confined to a small spot. (60bf7f2b-f4ed-4dec-9f48-7ef19513b9d8; 36038119-cda7-4dea-92f9-3f66da828c73)
- Representatives must be numerous enough to guard against cabals but limited enough to avoid the confusion of a multitude; the larger republic, if not less proportionally fertile in fit characters, will present advantages. (d0b94e48-3837-4b1b-923b-2622a0e65484; 66fdeb64-13d0-4ae7-893f-abc6cd764aff)
- Practical assurance example: a representative for every thirty thousand inhabitants will render the House both "a safe and competent guardian" of entrusted interests. (10231903-49b6-4358-bf6c-726f129b5dcf)
